{{corporal punishment}}
'''School [[corporal punishment]]''' refers to causing deliberate pain or discomfort in response to undesired behaviour by students in schools. It often involves striking the student either across the buttocks<ref>See e.g. [http://www.alex.k12.al.us/handbook/hand.pdf Student/Parent Information Guide and Code of Conduct 2008-2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824024436/http://www.alex.k12.al.us/handbook/hand.pdf |date=24 August 2009 }}, Alexander City Schools, Alabama, USA, p.44.</ref> or on the hands,<ref name="toronto"/> with an implement such as a rattan [[caning|cane]], wooden [[Paddle (spanking)|paddle]], [[Slippering (punishment)|slipper]], leather [[Strapping (punishment)|strap]] or wooden yardstick. Less commonly, it could also include [[spanking]] or smacking the student with the open hand, especially at the [[elementary school]] level.
In the English-speaking world, the use by schools of corporal punishment has historically been justified by the common-law doctrine ''[[in loco parentis]]'', whereby teachers are considered authority figures granted the same rights as parents to punish children in their care.
Advocates of school corporal punishment argue that it provides an immediate response to indiscipline and that the student is quickly back in the classroom learning, as opposed to [[Suspension (punishment)|suspension]] from school. Opponents, including a number of medical and psychological societies, along with [[human-rights]] groups, argue that physical punishment is ineffective in the long term, interferes with learning, leads to antisocial behavior as well as various forms of mental distress, disproportionately affects students of color, and is a form of violence that breaches the rights of children.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gershoff, E.T. & Font, S.A.|first=|date=2016|title=Corporal punishment in U.S. public schools: Prevalence, disparities in use, and status in state and federal policy|url=http://www.nospank.net/gershoff.pdf|journal=Society for Research and Child Development|volume=30|pages=1|via=}}</ref>
Poland was the first nation to outlaw corporal punishment in schools in 1783. School corporal punishment is no longer legal in any European country. As of 2016, an estimated 128 countries have prohibited corporal punishment in schools, including all of Europe, and most of South America and East Asia. Approximately 69 countries still allow for corporal punishment in schools, including parts of the [[United States]], some [[Australia]]n states, and a number of countries in Africa and Asia.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gershoff|first=Elizabeth|date=2017|title=School corporal punishment in global perspective: prevalence, outcomes, and efforts at intervention|journal=Psychology, Health & Medicine|volume=22|issue=sup1|pages=sup1, 224–239|doi=10.1080/13548506.2016.1271955|pmid=28064515|pmc=5560991}}</ref>
==Definitions== [[File:Koerperstrafe- MA Birkenrute.png|thumb|right|150px|Medieval schoolboy birched on the bare buttocks]] Corporal punishment in the context of schools in the late 20th and early 21st centuries has been variously defined as: causing deliberate pain to a child in response to the child's undesired behavior and/or language,<ref name=AACAP>{{cite web |title=Corporal Punishment in Schools |url=https://www.aacap.org/aacap/policy_statements/1988/Corporal_Punishment_in_Schools.aspx |publisher=American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry |date=September 2014}}</ref> "purposeful infliction of bodily pain or discomfort by an official in the educational system upon a student as a penalty for unacceptable behavior",<ref name=Pediatricians>{{cite journal |author=Poole, Steven R. |display-authors=etal |title=The role of the pediatrician in abolishing corporal punishment in schools |journal=Pediatrics |volume=88 |issue=1 |pages=162–7 |date=July 1991 |pmid=2057255 |doi= |url= }}</ref> and "intentional application of physical pain as a means of changing behavior" (not the occasional use of physical restraint to protect student or others from immediate harm).<ref name=SAM2003>{{cite journal |author1=Greydanus, D.E. |author2=Pratt, H.D. |author3=Spates, Richard C. |author4=Blake-Dreher, A.E. |author5=Greydanus-Gearhart, M.A. |author6=Patel, D.R. |title=Corporal punishment in schools: position paper of the Society for Adolescent Medicine |journal=J Adolesc Health |volume=32 |issue=5 |pages=385–93 |date=May 2003 |pmid=12729988 |doi=10.1016/S1054-139X(03)00042-9 |url=http://www.adolescenthealth.org/PositionPaper_Corporal_Punishment_in_Schools.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419115418/http://www.adolescenthealth.org/PositionPaper_Corporal_Punishment_in_Schools.pdf |archivedate=19 April 2009 }}</ref>
==Prevalence== Corporal punishment used to be prevalent in schools in many parts of the world, but in recent decades it has been outlawed in 128 countries including all of Europe, most of South America, as well as in Canada, Japan, South Africa, New Zealand and several other countries. It remains commonplace in a number of countries in Africa, [[Southeast Asia]], and the Middle East (see list of countries, below).
While most [[U.S. state]]s have outlawed corporal punishment in [[state school]]s, it continues to be allowed mainly in the [[Southern United States|Southern]] and [[Western United States|Western]] United States.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2012/03/13/148521155/spanking-lives-on-in-rural-florida-schools "Spanking Lives On In Rural Florida Schools"] (15 March 2012). NPR.</ref> According to the [[United States Department of Education]], more than 216,000 students were subjected to corporal punishment during the 2008{{ndash}}09 school year.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21632521-spanking-makes-your-children-stupid-spare-rod "Spare the rod"] (15 November 2014). ''The Economist''.</ref>
Much of the traditional culture that surrounds corporal punishment in school, at any rate in the [[English-speaking world]], derives largely from British practice in the 19th and 20th centuries, particularly as regards the caning of teenage boys.<ref name="corpunuk">[http://www.corpun.com/counuks.htm United Kingdom: Corporal punishment in schools] at World Corporal Punishment Research.</ref> There is a vast amount of literature on this, in both popular and serious culture.<ref>Quigly, Isabel (1984). ''The Heirs of Tom Brown: The English School Story''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-281404-4}}</ref><ref>Chandos, John (1984). ''Boys Together: English Public Schools 1800-1864''. London: Hutchinson, esp. chapter 11. {{ISBN|0-09-139240-3}}</ref> Britain itself outlawed the practice in 1987 for state schools<ref>{{Cite legislation UK | type = act | year = 1986 | chapter = 61 | act = Education (No. 2) Act 1986 }} Section 47 for England and Wales and section 48 for Scotland, brought into force in 1987.</ref><ref>[[Privy Council of the United Kingdom]]. ''[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/nisi/1987/461 Education (Corporal Punishment) (Northern Ireland) Order 1987]''.</ref><ref>Gould, Mark (9 January 2007). [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2007/jan/09/schools.uk1 "Sparing the rod"]. ''The Guardian'' (London).</ref> and more recently for all schools.<ref>{{Cite legislation UK | type = act | year = 1998 | chapter = 31 | act = School Standards and Framework Act 1998 }} Section 131, for England and Wales, brought into force in 1999.</ref><ref>Brown, Colin (25 March 1998). [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/last-vestiges-of-caning-swept-away-1152260.html "Last vestiges of caning swept away"]. ''The Independent'' (London).</ref>
The doctrine of ''[[in loco parentis]]'' lets school officials stand in for parents as comparable authority figures.<ref name=Pediatricians/> The doctrine has its origins in an [[English common-law]] precedent of 1770.<ref name=SAM2003/>
[[File:'February - Cutting Weather - Squally' - George Cruikshank, 1839 - BL.jpg|thumb|left|1839 caricature by [[George Cruikshank]] of a school flogging]] Many schools in [[Singapore]] and [[Malaysia]] use caning (for boys) as a routine official punishment for misconduct, as also some African countries. In some Middle Eastern countries whipping is used. (See list of countries, below.)
In most of continental Europe, school corporal punishment has been banned for several decades or longer, depending on the country (see the list of countries below).
From the 1917 Russian revolution onwards, corporal punishment was outlawed in the [[Soviet Union]], because it was deemed contrary to communist ideology.<ref name="Teitelbaum1945">Teitelbaum, Salomon M. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2491761 "Parental Authority in the Soviet Union"], in ''American Slavic and East European Review'', Vol. 4, No. 3/4 (December 1945), pp. 54-69.</ref> Communists in other countries such as Britain took the lead in campaigning against school corporal punishment, which they viewed as a symptom of the decadence of capitalist education systems.<ref>Linehan, Thomas P. (2007). [https://books.google.com/books?id=LY7QGOMIqRsC ''Communism in Britain, 1920-39: From the cradle to the grave''], Manchester University Press. pp. 32 ff. {{ISBN|0-7190-7140-2}}</ref> In the 1960s, Soviet visitors to western schools expressed shock at the caning of boys there.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/uksc6011.htm "Caning? It's not cricket, say the Russians at Rugby"]. ''Daily Mail'' (London). 22 November 1960.</ref> Other communist regimes followed suit: for instance, corporal punishment was "unknown" by students in North Korea in 2007.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/krs00703.htm#19022 "North Korean Defectors Face Huge Challenges"]. ''Radio Free Asia''. 21 March 2007.</ref> In mainland China, corporal punishment in schools was outlawed in 1986,<ref name="Country report for China">[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/china.html "Country report for China"]. Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children.</ref> although the practice remains common, especially in rural areas.<ref name="corpun.com">Paul Wiseman, [http://www.corpun.com/cns00005.htm "Chinese schools try to unlearn brutality"], ''USA Today'', Washington D.C., 9 May 2000.</ref>
According to the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], there are three broad rationales for the use of corporal punishment in schools: beliefs, based in traditional religion, that adults have a right, if not a duty, to physically punish misbehaving children; a disciplinary philosophy that corporal punishment builds character, being necessary for the development of a child's conscience and their respect for adult authority figures; and beliefs concerning the needs and rights of teachers, specifically that corporal punishment is essential for maintaining order and control in the classroom.<ref name=Pediatricians/>
==Effects on students== School officials and policymakers often rely on personal [[Anecdotal evidence|anecdotes]] to argue that school corporal punishment improves students' behavior and achievement.<ref name=Gershoff2010>{{cite journal |author=Gershoff, Elizabeth T. |date=Spring 2010 |title=More Harm Than Good: A Summary of Scientific Research on the Intended and Unintended Effects of Corporal Punishment on Children |url=http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/lcp/vol73/iss2/3/ |journal=Law & Contemporary Problems |volume=73 |issue=2 |pages=31–56}}</ref> However, there is a lack of empirical evidence showing that corporal punishment leads to better control in the classroom. In particular, evidence does not suggest that it enhances moral character development, increases students' respect for teachers or other authority figures, or offers greater security for teachers.<ref name="Greydanus">{{cite web|url=http://edworkforce.house.gov/uploadedfiles/04.15.10_greydandus.pdf|title=Corporal Punishment in Schools and its Effect on Academic Success: Testimony by Donald E. Greydanus MD|last=|first=|date=15 April 2010|website=|publisher=Healthy Families and Communities Subcommittee, United States House of Representatives |format=PDF|access-date=}}</ref>
A number of medical, pediatric or psychological societies have issued statements opposing all corporal punishment in schools, citing such outcomes as poorer academic achievement, increases in antisocial behaviour, injuries to students, and an unwelcoming learning environment. They include the [[American Medical Association]],<ref name="NCACPS list">[https://www.ama-assn.org/ssl3/ecomm/PolicyFinderForm.pl?site=www.ama-assn.org&uri=/resources/html/PolicyFinder/policyfiles/HnE/H-515.995.HTM "H-515.995 Corporal Punishment in Schools"]. American Medical Association.</ref> the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry,<ref name=AACAP/> the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP),<ref name=Pediatricians/><ref name="pmid6599942">{{cite journal |author=American Academy of Pediatrics, Committee on School Health |title=Corporal punishment in schools |journal=Pediatrics |volume=73 |issue=2 |pages=258 |date=February 1984 |pmid=6599942 |doi= |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=6599942}}</ref><ref name="pmid9521967">{{cite journal |author1=Stein, M.T. |author2=Perrin, E.L. |title=Guidance for effective discipline. American Academy of Pediatrics. Committee on Psychosocial Aspects of Child and Family Health |journal=Pediatrics |volume=101 |issue=4 Pt 1 |pages=723–8 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9521967 |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9521967}}</ref> the [[Society for Adolescent Medicine]],<ref name=SAM2003/><ref name="pmid1498122">{{cite journal |title=Corporal punishment in schools. A position paper of the Society for Adolescent Medicine |journal=J Adolesc Health |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=240–6 |date=May 1992 |pmid=1498122 |doi= |url=}}</ref> the [[American Psychological Association]],<ref>[http://www.apa.org/about/policy/corporal-punishment.aspx "Corporal Punishment"]. ''Council Policy Manual''. American Psychological Association. 1975.</ref> the [[Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rcpch.ac.uk/sites/default/files/asset_library/Policy%20and%20Standards/Policy%20Documents/Corporal%20Punishment%20Policy%20Nov09.pdf |title=Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health Position Statement on corporal punishment |date=November 2009}}</ref><ref name="pmid12949335">{{cite journal |author=Lynch, M. |title=Community pediatrics: role of physicians and organizations |journal=Pediatrics |volume=112 |issue=3 Part 2 |pages=732–4 |date=September 2003 |pmid=12949335|doi=10.1542/peds.112.3.S1.732 |doi-broken-date=2018-09-21 }}</ref> the [[Royal College of Psychiatrists]],<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/pb.2.4.62 |title=Memorandum on the Use of Corporal Punishment in Schools |year=1978 |journal=Psychiatric Bulletin |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=62–64}}</ref> the [[Canadian Paediatric Society]]<ref>{{cite journal|pmc=2719514 |title=Effective discipline for children |author1=Psychosocial Paediatrics Committee |author2=Canadian Paediatric Society |journal=Paediatrics & Child Health |year=2004 |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=37–41 |pmid=19654979}}</ref> and the [[Australian Psychological Society]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/lc/qalc.nsf/ad22cc96ba50555dca257051007aa5c8/ca25707400260aa3ca25706f0001d5c8!OpenDocument |title=Legislative assembly questions #0293 - Australian Psychological Society: Punishment and Behaviour Change |accessdate=6 August 2008 |date=20 October 1996 |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080503222048/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/lc/qalc.nsf/ad22cc96ba50555dca257051007aa5c8/ca25707400260aa3ca25706f0001d5c8!OpenDocument |archivedate = 3 May 2008}}</ref> as well as the United States' [[National Association of Secondary School Principals]].<ref name=Principals>{{cite web |url=http://www.principals.org/Content.aspx?topic=47093 |title=Corporal punishment |publisher=National Association of Secondary School Principals |date=February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203092131/http://www.principals.org/Content.aspx?topic=47093 |archivedate=3 December 2010 }}</ref>
According to the AAP, research shows that corporal punishment is less effective than other methods of behaviour management in schools, and "praise, discussions regarding values, and positive role models do more to develop character, respect, and values than does corporal punishment".<ref name=Pediatricians/> They say that evidence links corporal punishment of students to a number of adverse outcomes, including: "increased aggressive and destructive behaviour, increased disruptive classroom behaviour, vandalism, poor school achievement, poor attention span, increased drop-out rate, school avoidance and school phobia, low self-esteem, anxiety, somatic complaints, [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[suicide]] and retaliation against teachers".<ref name=Pediatricians/> The AAP recommends a number of alternatives to corporal punishment including various nonviolent behaviour-management strategies, modifications to the school environment, and increased support for teachers.<ref name=Pediatricians/>
===Injuries to students=== An estimated 1 to 2 percent of physically punished students in the United States are seriously injured, to the point of needing medical attention. According to the AAP and the Society for Adolescent Medicine, these injuries have included [[Ecchymosis|bruises]], [[Abrasion (medical)|abrasions]], [[Bone fracture|broken bones]], [[whiplash injury]], muscle damage, [[Traumatic brain injury|brain injury]], and even death.<ref name=Pediatricians/><ref name=SAM2003/> Other reported injuries to students include "[[Sciatica|sciatic nerve damage]]"<ref name=Pediatricians/> "extensive [[hematomas]]", and "life-threatening fat [[Bleeding|hemorrhage]]".<ref name=SAM2003/>
===Promotion of violence=== The AAP cautions that there is a risk of corporal punishment in schools [[Social learning theory|fostering the impression among students]] that violence is an appropriate means for managing others' behaviour.<ref name=Pediatricians/> According to the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, "Corporal punishment signals to the child that a way to settle interpersonal conflicts is to use physical force and inflict pain".<ref name=AACAP/> And according to the Society for Adolescent Medicine, "The use of corporal punishment in schools promotes a very precarious message: that violence is an acceptable phenomenon in our society. It sanctions the notion that it is meritorious to be violent toward our children, thereby devaluing them in society's eyes. It encourages children to resort to violence because they see their authority figures or substitute parents doing it [...] Violence is not acceptable and we must not support it by sanctioning its use by such authority figures as school officials".<ref name=SAM2003/>
==Alternatives== The Society for Adolescent Medicine recommends developing "a milieu of effective communication, in which the teacher displays an attitude of respect for the students", as well as instruction that is stimulating and appropriate to student's abilities, various nonviolent behaviour modification techniques, and involving students and parents in making decisions about school matters such as rules and educational goals. They suggest that student self-governance can be an effective alternative for managing disruptive classroom behaviour, while stressing the importance of adequate training and support for teachers.<ref name=SAM2003/>
The AAP remarks that there has been "no reported increase in disciplinary problems in schools following the elimination of corporal punishment" according to evidence.<ref name=Pediatricians/>
==Student rights== A number of international human-rights organizations including the [[Committee on the Rights of the Child|UN Committee on the Rights of the Child]], the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]], and the [[Inter-American Commission on Human Rights]] have stated that physical punishment of any kind is a violation of children's human rights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/460bc7772.html |title= General comment No. 8 (2006): The right of the child to protection from corporal punishment and or cruel or degrading forms of punishment (articles 1, 28(2), and 37, inter alia) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2 March 2007 |publisher= United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child, 42nd Sess., U.N. Doc. CRC/C/GC/8 |accessdate= January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=/Documents/AdoptedText/ta04/EREC1666.htm#_ftn1 |title=Europe-Wide Ban on Corporal Punishment of Children, Recommendation 1666 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=23 June 2004 |publisher=Parliamentary Assembly, Council of Europe (21st Sitting) |accessdate=January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220063001/http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta04%2FEREC1666.htm#_ftn1 |archivedate=20 February 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cidh.oas.org/Ninez/CastigoCorporal2009/CastigoCorporal.TOC.htm |title= Report on Corporal Punishment and Human Rights of Children and Adolescents |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=5 August 2009 |publisher= Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, Rapporteurship on the Rights of the Child, Organization of American States |accessdate= January 2015}}</ref>
According to the Committee on the Rights of the Child, "Children do not lose their human rights by virtue of passing through the school gates [...] the use of corporal punishment does not respect the inherent dignity of the child nor the strict limits on school discipline".<ref>Committee on the Rights of the Child (2001). [https://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/crc/comment1.htm ''General Comment No. 1, The Aims of Education''.] U.N. Doc. CRC/GC/2001/1.</ref> The Committee interprets Article 19 of the [[Convention on the rights of the child]], which obliges member states to "take all appropriate legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to protect the child from all forms of physical or mental violence, injury or abuse […] while in the care of parent(s), legal guardian(s) or any other person who has the care of the child", to imply a prohibition on all forms of corporal punishment.
Other international human-rights bodies supporting prohibition of corporal punishment of children in all settings, including schools, include the [[European Committee of Social Rights]] and the [[African Committee of Experts on the Rights and Welfare of the Child]]. In addition, the obligation of member states to prohibit corporal punishment in schools and elsewhere was affirmed in the 2009 Cairo Declaration on the Convention on the Rights of the Child and Islamic Jurisprudence.<ref name=Report2015>{{citation |title=Towards Non-violent Schools: Prohibiting All Corporal Punishment: Global Report 2015 |format=PDF |location=London |publisher=Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children; Save the Children |date=May 2015 |url=http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/assets/pdfs/reports-thematic/Schools%20Report%202015-EN.pdf}}</ref>
==By country== {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 | image1 = Corporal punishment in the United States.svg | caption1 = [[School corporal punishment in the United States]]<br> [[Corporal punishment of minors in the United States]]<br> <!---->{{legend|#0000d8|Corporal punishment illegal in schools only}} {{legend|#c70909|Corporal punishment not illegal}} | image2 = Corporal punishment in Europe.svg | caption2 = Legality of corporal punishment of minors in Europe ---- {{legend|#09c70d|Corporal punishment illegal in both schools and the home}} {{legend|#0000d8|Corporal punishment illegal in schools only}} {{legend|#c70909|Corporal punishment legal in schools and in the home}} }}
According to the [[Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children]], all forms of corporal punishment in schools are outlawed in 128 countries as of 2016.<ref name=":1" /> (46 of these countries also prohibited corporal punishment of children in the home as of May 2015).<ref name=Report2015/>
===Argentina=== Banned in 1813, corporal punishment was re-legalised in 1815 and punishments by physical pain lasted legally till 1884, when it was banned again unless there was a Court order. The instruments were [[rebenque]]s, [[Slapping (strike)|slapping]]s in the face and others.<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2005/12/17/sociedad/s-06901.htm "Diálogo, premios y penitencias: cómo poner límites sin violencia"]. ''El Clarín'' (Buenos Aires). 17 December 2005. {{Link language|es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/1999/02/10/e-04402d.htm "En Argentina, del golpe a la convivencia"]. ''El Clarín'' (Buenos Aires). 10 February 1999. {{Link language|es}}</ref> All corporal punishment in children is prohibited everywhere (schools, home, etc) since 2016.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/argentina.html "Country report for Argentina"]. Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children.</ref>
===Australia=== In Australia, laws on corporal punishment in schools are determined at individual state or territory level.<ref>{{citation|title=Corporal punishment: Key issues - Resource Sheet |url= http://www.aifs.gov.au/nch/pubs/sheets/rs19/rs19.html |publisher=Australian Government |author=Child Family Community Australia |date=March 2014 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150911090109/https://aifs.gov.au/cfca/publications/corporal-punishment-key-issues |deadurl=no |archivedate=11 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-16/kevin-donnelly-slammed-over-corporal-punishment-comments/5600408 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141114163817/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-16/kevin-donnelly-slammed-over-corporal-punishment-comments/5600408 |archivedate=14 November 2014 |title=Federal Government rules out return of corporal punishment, after curriculum adviser says it can be 'very effective' |date=16 July 2014 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |deadurl=no}}</ref> While still legal in private schools in some states, in practice, very few schools impose corporal punishment.<ref>{{cite news |last=Barrett |first=Rosanne |title= States refuse to buckle amid calls to ban cane |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/education/states-refuse-to-buckle-amid-calls-to-ban-cane/story-fn59nlz9-1226407027267?nk=102c09b31b32468c992870ae47532208 |date=25 June 2012 |newspaper =The Australian |accessdate=15 February 2015 |location=Sydney}}</ref>

Education Bill - Committee |url= http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/hansard/hans35.nsf/c02fad1ff7f00ecbc82572e4002d0af9/a005162d3d01eaff4825662c000fcb03?OpenDocument |website=Hansard |publisher=Parliament of Western Australia |accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref> || Banned in 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title=Last WA school using corporal punishment forced to end practice from next term |date=7 January 2015 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150130083847/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-01-07/last-school-to-cease-corporal-punishment-in-wa/6004992 |archivedate=30 January 2015 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-01-07/last-school-to-cease-corporal-punishment-in-wa/6004992 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |newspaper=The Australian |first=Andrew |last=Burrell |date=8 January 2015 |title=Corporal punishment ban widened |page=3}}</ref> |}
===Austria=== Corporal punishment in schools was banned in Austria in 1974.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/austria.html Austria State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820161232/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/austria.html |date=20 August 2008 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref>
===Bolivia=== Corporal punishment in all settings, including schools, was prohibited in [[Bolivia]] in 2014. According to the Children and Adolescents Code, "The child and adolescent has the right to good treatment, comprising a non-violent upbringing and education... Any physical, violent and humiliating punishment is prohibited".<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/prohibiting-states/bolivia.html "Prohibition of all corporal punishment in Bolivia (2014)"]. Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children.</ref>
===Brazil=== Corporal punishment in all settings, including schools, was prohibited in [[Brazil]] in 2014. According to an amendment to the Code on Children and Adolescents 1990, "Children and Adolescents are entitled to be educated and cared for without the use of physical punishment or cruel or degrading treatment as forms of correction, discipline, education or any other pretext".<ref>[https://www.savethechildren.org.za/Brazil_BansCorporalPunishment "Brazil Prohibits All Corporal Punishment"]. Save the Children. 2 July 2014.</ref>
===Burma (Myanmar)=== Caning is commonly used by teachers as a punishment in schools.<ref>{{cite news |title= Corporal punishment 'common practice': author |url= http://www.mmtimes.com/feature/investing/inv009.htm |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140324095053/http://www.mmtimes.com/feature/investing/inv009.htm |archivedate=24 March 2014 |newspaper=The Mayanmar Times |location= Yangon |first=Juliet |last=Shwe Gaung |date=26 January 2009}}</ref> The cane is applied on the students' buttocks, calves or palms of the hands in front of the class. Tramline cane marks could be left. Sit-ups with ears pulled and arms crossed, kneeling, and standing on the bench in the classroom are other forms of corporal punishments used in schools. Common reasons for punishment include talking in class, not finishing homework, mistakes made with classwork, fighting and truancy.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/special-features/165-back-to-school-2013/6752-against-the-cane-corporal-punishment-in-myanmar.html |title=Against the cane: corporal punishment in Myanmar |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140324094044/http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/special-features/165-back-to-school-2013/6752-against-the-cane-corporal-punishment-in-myanmar.html |archivedate=24 March 2014 |date=13 May 2013 |first=Jessica |last=Mudditt |newspaper=The Mayanmar Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.myanmar.gov.mm/Article/Article2002/apr/apr23a.htm |title= Slate & Slate Pencil - Computer & Keyboard |work= The New Light of Myanmar |first=Ma |last=Ohmar |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050425065540/http://www.myanmar.gov.mm/Article/Article2002/apr/apr23a.htm |archivedate=25 April 2005 |date=23 April 2002}}</ref>
===Canada=== In ''[[Canadian Foundation for Children, Youth and the Law v. Canada (Attorney General)|Canadian Foundation for Children, Youth and the Law v. Canada]]'' (2004) the [[Supreme Court of Canada|Supreme Court]] outlawed school corporal punishment.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/cas00402.htm#12652 "Supreme Court takes strap out of teachers' hands"]. ''Edmonton Journal'' (Alberta). 1 February 2004.</ref> In public schools, the usual implement was a rubber/canvas strap applied to the hands,<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/cascr1.htm Moyers school supplies catalogue], 1971.</ref> while private schools often used a paddle or cane administered to the student's posterior.<ref>FitzGerald, James (1994).[https://web.archive.org/web/20041010223331/http://www.pathcom.com/~jfitzg/oldboys_excerpts_ucc.htm ''Old Boys: The Powerful Legacy of Upper Canada College'']. Toronto: Macfarlane Walter & Ross. {{ISBN|0-921912-74-9}}</ref><ref>Byfield, Ted (21 October 1996). [http://www.corpun.com/casc9610.htm#11375 "Do our new-found ideas on children maybe explain the fact we can't control them?"]. ''Alberta Report'' (Edmonton).</ref> In many parts of Canada, 'the strap' had not been used in public schools since the 1970s or even earlier: thus, it has been claimed that it had not been used in [[Quebec]] since the 1960s,<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/cad00502.htm#16725 "Spanking still legal in Canada"]. ''Montreal Gazette''. 23 February 2005.</ref> and in Toronto it was banned in 1971.<ref name="toronto">[http://www.corpun.com/casc7107.htm "Toronto abolishes the strap"]. ''Globe and Mail'' (Toronto). 23 July 1971.</ref> However, some schools in [[Alberta]] had been using the strap up until the ban in 2004.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/cas00411.htm#14685 "Peace Wapiti scraps strap"]. ''Daily Herald-Tribune'' (Grande Prairie, Alberta). 19 November 2004.</ref>
====School Corporal Punishment Bans in Canadian Provinces==== In 2004, the Supreme Court of Canada outlawed corporal punishment in all schools, public or private. The practice itself had largely been abandoned in the 1970s when parents placed greater scrutiny on the treatment of children at school.<ref>http://www.corpun.com/cad00502.htm#16725</ref> The subject received extensive media coverage, and corporal punishment became obsolete as the practice was widely seen as degrading and inhumane. Despite the fact that the tradition had been forgone for nearly 30 years, legislation banning the practice entirely by law was not implemented until 2004.<ref>http://historyofrights.ca/encyclopaedia/main-events/corporal-punishment/</ref>
Some Canadian provinces banned corporal punishment in public schools prior to the national ban in 2004. They are, in chronological order by year of provincial ban:{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
*[[British Columbia]] - 1973 *[[Nova Scotia]] - 1989 *[[New Brunswick]] - 1990 *[[Yukon]] - 1990 *[[Prince Edward Island]] - 1993 *[[Northwest Territories]] - 1995 *[[Nunavut]] - 1995* (banned while Nunavut was still part of Northwest Territories. Remained banned in Nunavut when it became a separate Territory in 1999.) *[[Newfoundland and Labrador]] - 1997 *[[Quebec]] - 1998
===China=== Corporal punishment in China was officially banned after the communist revolution in 1949. The Compulsory Education Law of 1986 states: "It shall be forbidden to inflict physical punishment on students".<ref name="Country report for China"/> In practice, beatings by schoolteachers are common, especially in rural areas.<ref name="corpun.com"/><ref>[http://english.people.com.cn/200507/31/eng20050731_199408.html "New measures taken in schools to improve teacher-student relations"], ''People's Daily'', Beijing, 31 July 2005.</ref>
=== Colombia === Colombian private and public schools were banned from using "penalties involving physical or psychological abuse" through the Children and Adolescents Code 2006, though it is not clear whether this also applies to indigenous communities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/colombia.html|title=Colombia country report - Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children|website=www.endcorporalpunishment.org|access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Not sure if site is reliable per WP's guidelines|date=March 2018}}
===Costa Rica=== All corporal punishment, both in school and in the home, has been banned since 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ticotimes.net/2008/06/27/costa-rica-lawmakers-ban-spanking |title=Costa Rica lawmakers ban spanking |first=Gillian |last=Gillers |work=[[The Tico Times]] |date=27 June 2008 |accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref>
===Czech Republic=== Corporal punishment is outlawed under Article 31 of the Education Act.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/czech.html Czech Republic State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090708074804/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/czech.html |date=8 July 2009 }}, GITEACPOC, June 2011.</ref>
===Denmark=== Corporal punishment was prohibited in the public schools in Copenhagen Municipality in 1951 and by law in all schools of Denmark in 1967.<ref>[http://danmarkshistorien.dk/leksikon-og-kilder/vis/materiale/skole-og-undervisning-1814-2014/ Danish School History 1814-2014], Danmarkshistorien.dk, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://denstoredanske.dk/Erhverv,_karriere_og_ledelse/P%C3%A6dagogik_og_uddannelse/Skole_og_SFO/dansk_skolehistorie Danish School History], Den Store Danske Encyklopædi.</ref><ref>[https://www.folkeskolen.dk/15196/laererens-ulovlige-lussinger Illegal corporal punishment], Folkeskolen, 3 October 2002.</ref>
===Egypt=== A 1998 study found that random physical punishment (not proper formal corporal punishment) was being used extensively by teachers in [[Egypt]] to punish behavior they regarded as unacceptable. Around 80% of the boys and 60% of the girls were punished by teachers, using their hands, sticks, straps, shoes, punches and kicks as most common methods of administration. The most common reported [[injuries]] were bumps and [[contusions]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Youssef RM, Attia MS, Kamel MI |title=Children experiencing violence. II: Prevalence and determinants of corporal punishment in schools |journal=Child Abuse Negl |volume=22 |issue=10 |pages=975–85 |date=October 1998 |pmid=9793720 |doi= 10.1016/S0145-2134(98)00084-2|url=|last2=Attia |last3=Kamel }}</ref>
===Finland=== Corporal punishment in public schools was banned in 1914, but remained ''de facto'' commonplace until 1984, when a law banning all corporal punishment of minors, even by parents, was introduced.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kolsi|first1=Eeva-Kaarina|title=Kansakoulun perustamisesta 150 vuotta – lukemisen pelättiin laiskistavan|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/kotimaa/art-2000001195785.html|accessdate=10 September 2016|work=[[Ilta-Sanomat]]|date=11 June 2016|language=Finnish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Autio|first1=Raisa|title=Lasten ruumiillinen kuritus kiellettiin 30 vuotta sitten – vielä joka neljäs tukistaa|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/lasten_ruumiillinen_kuritus_kiellettiin_30_vuotta_sitten__viela_joka_neljas_tukistaa/7182651|accessdate=10 September 2016|work=[[YLE]] Uutiset|date=9 April 2014|language=Finnish}}</ref>
===France=== The systematic use of corporal punishment has been absent from French schools since the 19th century.<ref>"The punishments in French schools are impositions and confinements."-- [[Matthew Arnold]] (1861) cited in Robert McCole Wilson, [http://www.zona-pellucida.com/wilson04.html ''A Study of Attitudes Towards Corporal Punishment as an Educational Procedure From the Earliest Times to the Present''], Nijmegen University, 1999, 4.3.</ref> There is no explicit legal ban on it,<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/france.html France State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120191943/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/france.html |date=20 November 2008 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref> but in 2008 a teacher was fined €500 for what some people describe as slapping a student.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1832792,00.html "Teacher Fined, Praised for Slap"], [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] (New York), 14 August 2008.</ref><ref>Desnos, Marie (13 August 2008). [http://www.lejdd.fr/Societe/Actualite/Une-gifle-a-500-euros-88735 "Une gifle à 500 euros"]. ''[[Le Journal du Dimanche]]'' (Paris).</ref><ref>Rosenczveig, Jean-Pierre (1 February 2008).[http://jprosen.blog.lemonde.fr/2008/02/01/violences-non-retenues-au-college-239/ "Violences non retenues au collège"].</ref>
===Germany=== School corporal punishment, historically widespread, was outlawed in different states via their administrative law at different times. It was not completely abolished everywhere until 1983.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/desc8707.htm "It's 40 years since corporal punishment got a general boot"], translated from ''Saarbrücker Zeitung'', 19 June 1987.</ref> Since 1993, use of corporal punishment by a teacher has been a criminal offence. In that year a sentence by the [[Federal Court of Justice of Germany]] (''Bundesgerichtshof'', case number NStZ 1993.591) was published which overruled the previous powers enshrined in unofficial [[custom (law)|customary law]] (''Gewohnheitsrecht'') and upheld by some [[Oberlandesgericht|regional appeal courts]] (''Oberlandesgericht'', Superior State Court) even in the 1970s. They assumed a ''right of chastisement'' was a [[Justification (jurisprudence)|defense of justification]] against the accusation of "causing bodily harm" per ''Paragraph'' (=Section) ''223 [[Strafgesetzbuch]]'' (Federal Penal Code).
===Greece=== Corporal punishment in Greek primary schools was banned in 1998, and in secondary schools in 2005.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/greece.html Greece State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908013303/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/greece.html |date=8 September 2008 }}, GITEACPOC, November 2006.</ref>
===India=== {{see also|Socio-economic issues in India}} Corporal punishment is still used in most of India. The Delhi High Court banned its use in Delhi schools in 2000. 17 out of 29 states claim to apply the ban, though enforcement is lax.<ref>Nilanjana Bhowmick (2 May 2009). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1895495,00.html "Why India's Teachers Do Not Spare the Rod"]. ''Time'' (New York).</ref> A number of social and cultural groups, including [[Shankaracharya]], are campaigning against corporal punishment in India. In many states, corporal punishment is still practised within most schools. Society for Prevention of Injuries & Corporal Punishment (SPIC) is actively running awareness campaigns to educate the teachers and students through conferences and scientific publications.<ref>http://forensicwayout.com/SPIC/tabid/127/Default.aspx</ref>
===Ireland=== In the [[law of the Republic of Ireland]], corporal punishment was prohibited in 1982 by an administrative decision of [[John Boland (Fine Gael politician)|John Boland]], the [[Minister for Education and Skills|Minister for Education]], which applied to [[national school (Ireland)|national schools]] (most primary schools) and to secondary schools receiving public funding (practically all of them).<ref> * {{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/sendebates/?id=2015-10-21a.100#g107|title=Children First Bill 2014: Report|date=21 October 2015|work=Seanad debates|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=21 November 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.education.ie/en/Circulars-and-Forms/Active-Circulars/p_abolition_corporal_punishment.pdf |title=R.R. 144329 / Circular 9/82 / Re: The Abolition of Corporal Punishment in National Schools |author=Primary Branch|date=January 1982|work=Circulars|publisher=Department of Education|accessdate=21 November 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.education.ie/en/Circulars-and-Forms/Active-Circulars/pp_abolition_corporal_punishment.pdf |title=Circular M5/82 / Abolition of Corporal Punishment in Schools in respect of Financial Aid from the Department of Education. |author=Post-Primary Branch|date=January 1982|work=Circulars|publisher=Department of Education|accessdate=21 November 2017}} </ref> Teachers were not liable to criminal prosecution until 1997, when the [[rule of law]] allowing "physical [[chastisement]]" was explicitly abolished.<ref> * {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1997/act/26/section/24/enacted/en/html#sec24|title=Non-Fatal Offences Against the Person Act, 1997, Section 24|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=21 November 2017}} * {{cite web|url=https://beta.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/seanad/1997-05-07/9/ |title=Non-Fatal Offences Against the Person Bill, 1997: Second Stage |date=7 May 1997 |work=Seanad Éireann Debates |quote=The use of force by teachers, following the enactment of the Bill, will be governed, as in the case of other people, by the rules set out in sections 18 and 19.|accessdate=21 November 2017}} </ref>
===Italy=== Corporal punishment in Italian schools was banned in 1928.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/italy.html Italy State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725033425/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/italy.html |date=25 July 2008 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref>
===Japan=== Although banned in 1947, corporal punishment is still commonly found in schools in the 2010s and particularly widespread in school sports clubs. In late 1987, about 60% of junior high school teachers felt it was necessary, with 7% believing it was necessary in all conditions, 59% believing it should be applied sometimes and 32% disapproving of it in all circumstances; while at elementary (primary) schools, 2% supported it unconditionally, 47% felt it was necessary and 49% disapproved.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/jpsc8711.htm "Many Japanese Teachers Favor Corporal Punishment"], ''Nichi Bei Times'', San Francisco, 21 November 1987.</ref> As recent as December 2012, a high school student committed suicide after having been constantly beaten by his basketball coach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/student-commits-suicide-after-being-beaten-by-school-basketball-coach|title=Student commits suicide after being beaten by school basketball coach ' Japan Today: Japan News and Discussion|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> An education ministry survey found that more than 10,000 students received illegal corporal punishment from more than 5,000 teachers across Japan in 2012 fiscal year alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/06/03/national/corporal-punishment-rife-in-schools-in-2012-survey/#.UjrOacZ6aQk|title=Corporal punishment rife in schools in 2012: survey|work=The Japan Times|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
===Luxembourg=== Corporal punishment in schools was banned in 1845 and became a criminal offence in 1974 (Aggravated Assault on Minors under Authority). <ref>Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children, Report of corporal punishment of children in Luxembourg 2013</ref><ref>Legilux, Législation sur les mesures de discipline dans les écoles 2015</ref>
===Malaysia=== {{see also|Caning in Malaysia}} [[Image:Hand caning.jpg|thumb|right|160px|A picture showing the marks left on a Malaysian female student's palm after a caning]] Caning is a common form of discipline in many Malaysian schools. Legally it should be applied only to male students, but the idea of making the caning of girls lawful has recently been debated. This would be applied to the palm of the hand, whereas boys are typically caned across the seat of the trousers.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/counmy.htm#scp School corporal punishment in Malaysia] at World Corporal Punishment Research.</ref>
===Netherlands=== Banned in 1920.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/netherlands.html Netherlands State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081003230250/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/netherlands.html |date=3 October 2008 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref>
===New Zealand=== Corporal punishment in New Zealand schools was abolished in 1987, but wasn't abolished legislatively until 23 July 1990, when Section 139A of the [[Education Act 1989]] was inserted by the Education Amendment Act 1990. Section 139A prohibits anyone employed by a school or ECE provider, or anyone supervising or controlling students on the school's behalf, from using force by way of correction or punishment towards any student at or in relation to the school or the student under their supervision or control.<ref name="NZ legislation">{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0080/latest/contents.html |title= Education Act 1989 - New Zealand Legislation |publisher= New Zealand Parliamentary Counsel Office |accessdate = 9 January 2011}}</ref> Teachers who administer corporal punishment can be found guilty of physical assault, resulting in [[termination of employment|termination]] and cancellation of teacher registration, and possibly criminal charges, with a maximum penalty of five years' imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1961/0043/latest/DLM329725.html |title= §202C: Assault with weapon - Crimes Act 1961 No 43 as of 18 April 2012 - New Zealand Legislation |publisher= Parliamentary Counsel Office (New Zealand) |date= 18 April 2012 |accessdate= 11 May 2012}}</ref>
As enacted, the law had a loophole: parents, provided they were not school staff, could still discipline their children on school grounds. In early 2007, a southern Auckland Christian school was found to be using this loophole to discipline students by corporal punishment, by making the student's parents administer the punishment.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/content/994345/423466.html |title= School in corporal punishment spotlight |work = Television New Zealand |date=18 February 2007 |accessdate= 9 January 2011}}</ref> This loophole was closed in May 2007 by the [[Crimes (Substituted Section 59) Amendment Act 2007]], which enacted a blanket ban on parents administering corporal punishment to their children.
===Norway=== Corporal punishment in Norwegian schools was strongly restricted in 1889, and was prohibited outright in 1936.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
===Pakistan=== School corporal punishment in [[Pakistan]] is not very common in modern educational institutions although it is still used in schools across the rural parts of the country as a means of enforcing student discipline. The method has been criticised by some children's rights activists who claim that many cases of corporal punishment in schools have resulted in physical and mental abuse of schoolchildren. According to one report, corporal punishment is a key reason for school dropouts and subsequently, [[street children]], in Pakistan; as many as 35,000 high school pupils in Pakistan are said to drop out of the education system each year because they have been punished or abused in school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportId=78275|title=PAKISTAN: Corporal punishment key reason for school dropouts|work=IRIN Asia|date=18 May 2008}}</ref>
===Philippines=== Corporal punishment is prohibited in private and public schools.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/phillipines.html Philippines State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711160219/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/phillipines.html |date=11 July 2009 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref>
===Poland=== In 1783, Poland became the first country in the world to prohibit corporal punishment.<ref name="coe.int">{{cite book|title=Abolishing corporal punishment of children : questions and answers.|date=December 2007|publisher=Council of Europe|location=Strasbourg|isbn=978-9-287-16310-3|url=http://www.coe.int/t/dg3/children/corporalpunishment/pdf/EnglishQuestionAnswer_en.pdf|pages=31–32|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809054408/http://www.coe.int/t/dg3/children/corporalpunishment/pdf/EnglishQuestionAnswer_en.pdf|archivedate=9 August 2014}}</ref> Peter Newell assumes that perhaps the most influential writer on the subject was the English philosopher [[John Locke]], whose ''[[Some Thoughts Concerning Education]]'' explicitly criticised the central role of corporal punishment in education. Locke's work was highly influential, and may have helped influence Polish legislators to ban corporal punishment from Poland's schools in 1783. Today, the ban of corporal punishment in all forms is vested in [[Constitution of Poland]].<ref>Newell, Peter (ed.). ''A Last Resort? Corporal Punishment in Schools'', Penguin, London, 1972, p. 9. {{ISBN|0-14-080698-9}}</ref><ref name=Article40>Article 40th of the Constitution of Poland, 1997, http://www.sejm.gov.pl/prawo/konst/angielski/kon1.htm</ref>
===Russia=== Corporal punishment was banned in [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] (and hence, Russian) schools in 1917.<ref name="Teitelbaum1945"/> In addition, the Article 336 (since 2006) of the Labor Code of the Russian Federation states that any teacher who has used corporal punishment on a pupil shall be dismissed.
===Serbia=== Corporal punishment was first explicitly prohibited in schools in article 67 of the Law on Public Schools 1929, passed in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, of which Serbia was then a part. Other now independent countries which belonged to Yugoslavia then and to which the 1929 Law applied are: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Kosovo, and Slovenia. In Serbia, corporal punishment in schools is now unlawful under the Law on Secondary Schools 1992, the Law on Elementary Schools 1992 and the Law on the Foundations of Education and Upbringing 2003/2009.<ref>Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children, Country Report for Serbia, updated February 2018, http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/serbia.html. </ref>
===Singapore=== {{Main article|Caning in Singapore#School caning}} Corporal punishment is legal in Singapore schools (for male students only, it is illegal to inflict it on female students) and fully encouraged by the government in order to maintain strict discipline.<ref>[http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/speeches/2004/sp20040514.htm Speech by Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Acting Minister for Education.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125012554/http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/speeches/2004/sp20040514.htm |date=25 January 2009 }}</ref> Only a light rattan cane may be used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corpun.com/sgscr1.htm|title=WORLD CORPORAL PUNISHMENT: SCHOOL CANING IN SINGAPORE|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> This must be administered in a formal ceremony by the school management after due deliberation, not by classroom teachers. Most secondary schools (whether independent, autonomous or government-controlled), and also some primary schools, use caning to deal with misconduct by boys.<ref>[http://www.corpun.com/usscr2c.htm#singapore Singapore school handbooks on line] at World Corporal Punishment Research.</ref> At the secondary level, the rattan strokes are nearly always delivered to the student's clothed buttocks. The Ministry of Education has stipulated a maximum of six strokes per occasion. In some cases the punishment is carried out in front of the rest of the school instead of in private.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.corpun.com/counsgs.htm |title= Singapore: Corporal punishment in schools |author= Farrell, C. |date=June 2014 |publisher= World Corporal Punishment Research |accessdate=12 November 2015}}</ref>
===South Africa=== The use of corporal punishment in schools was prohibited by the [[South African Schools Act, 1996]]. According to section 10 of the act: {{quote|(1) No person may administer corporal punishment at a school to a learner.
(2) Any person who contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence and liable on conviction to a sentence which could be imposed for [[assault#South Africa|assault]].<ref>[http://www.info.gov.za/view/DownloadFileAction?id=70921 South African Schools Act, 1996, Chapter 2: Learners, Section 10: Prohibition of corporal punishment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130827233329/http://www.info.gov.za/view/DownloadFileAction?id=70921 |date=27 August 2013 }}</ref>}}
In the case of ''[[Christian Education South Africa v Minister of Education]]'' the [[Constitutional Court (South Africa)|Constitutional Court]] rejected a claim that the constitutional right to religious freedom entitles private Christian schools to impose corporal punishment.
===South Korea=== Liberal regions in South Korea have completely banned all forms of caning beginning with [[Gyeonggi Province]] in 2010, followed by [[Seoul|Seoul Metropolitan City]], [[Gangwon Province, South Korea|Gangwon Province]], [[Gwangju Metropolitan City]] and [[North Jeolla Province]] in 2011.<ref>http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=001&aid=0004972496</ref> Other more conservative regions are governed by a national law enacted in 2011 which states that while caning is generally forbidden, it can be used indirectly to maintain school discipline.<ref>[http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/society/schooling/469496.html 진보교육감들 “학생 간접체벌 불허”], 《한겨레》, 2011.3.23</ref> It is still known to be practised.<ref>[http://hankookilbo.com/m/v/1f2783bed47549688efc4b2f25e8d609 학교 체벌 일상화],''hankukilbo''south korea,2014.06.27</ref>
===Spain=== Corporal punishment in Spanish schools was banned in 1985.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/spain.html Spain State Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081103150421/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/spain.html |date=3 November 2008 }}, GITEACPOC.</ref>
===Sweden=== Corporal punishment at school has been prohibited in ''folkskolestadgan'' (the elementary school ordinance) since 1 January 1958. Its use by ordinary teachers in grammar schools had been outlawed in 1928.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aare.edu.au/97pap/johau029.htm | title = Changing concepts of Grammar School teacher authority in Sweden 1927-1965 | publisher = Australian Association for Research in Education | year = 1997}}</ref>
===Taiwan=== In 2006 Taiwan made corporal punishment in the school system illegal,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/6215949.stm "Taiwan corporal punishment banned"], ''BBC News On Line'', London, 29 December 2006.</ref> but it is still known to be practised (see [[Corporal punishment in Taiwan]]).
===Tanzania=== In [[Tanzania]] corporal punishment in schools is widely practised and has lead to lasting damage including death of a punished pupil. The Education Act of 2002 authorizes the minister in charge of education to issue regulations concerning corporal punishment. The Education (Corporal Punishment) Regulation G.N. 294 of 2002 gives the authority to order corporal punishment to the headmaster of a school who can delegate to any teacher on case by case basis. The number of strikes must not be more than 4 for each occurrence, The school should have a register where date, reason, name of pupil and of administering teacher together with the number of strikes is to be recorded <ref>[http://www.mwananchi.co.tz/habari/Makala/Ijue-sheria-ya-viboko-shuleni/1597592-4739596-loiigkz/index.html Ijue sheria ya viboko vya wanafunzi], Mwananchi newspaper 2 September 2018</ref>.
===Thailand=== Corporal punishment in schools is illegal under the Ministry of Education Regulation on Student Punishment (2005) and the National Committee on Child Protection Regulation on Working Procedures of Child Protection Officers Involved in Promoting Behaviour of Students (2005), pursuant to article 65 of the Child Protection Act.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/thailand.html#Lawfulness "Legality of corporal punishment in Thailand"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813011454/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/thailand.html |date=13 August 2014 }}, ''End Corporal Punishment'', February 2009.</ref>
Thai proverb ''"If you love your cow, tie it up; if you love your child, beat him."'' is still considered "wisdom" and is held by many parents and teachers.<ref>https://seap.einaudi.cornell.edu/proverbs</ref>
===Ukraine=== Corporal punishment was banned in Soviet (and hence, Ukrainian) schools in 1917.<ref name="Teitelbaum1945"/> In Ukraine, "physical or mental violence" against children is forbidden by the Constitution (Art.52.2) and the Law on Education (Art.51.1, since 1991) which states that students and other learners have the right “to the protection from any form of exploitation, physical and psychological violence, actions of pedagogical and other employees who violate the rights or humiliate their honour and dignity”.<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/pdfs/states-reports/Ukraine.pdf Ukraine. DETAILED COUNTRY REPORT] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722092738/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/pdfs/states-reports/Ukraine.pdf |date=22 July 2011 }}. Last updated: February 2011.</ref> Standard instructions for teachers provided by the Ministry of Science and Education state that a teacher who has used corporal punishment to a pupil (even once), shall be dismissed.
===United Arab Emirates=== A federal law was implemented in 1998 which banned school corporal punishment. The law applied to all schools, both public and private.<ref>http://www.khda.gov.ae/pages/en/commonQuestionssch.aspx</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/education/corporal-punishment-ban-makes-discipline-almost-impossible-say-uae-teachers|title=Corporal punishment ban makes discipline 'almost impossible' say UAE teachers|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> Any teacher who engages in the practice would not only lose their job and teaching license, but will also face criminal prosecution for engaging in violence against minors and will also face child abuse charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/education/uae-teacher-banned-after-forcing-child-to-remove-shirt-in-class|title=UAE teacher banned after forcing child to remove shirt in class|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== [[File:Punishment-record.jpg|thumb|Excerpt from a caning record of a British school (1970)]] In state-run schools, and in private schools where at least part of the funding came from government, corporal punishment was outlawed by the [[British Parliament]] in 1986, following a 1982 ruling by the European Court of Human Rights that such punishment could not be administered without parental consent, and that a child's "right to education" could not be infringed by suspending children who, with parental approval, refused to submit to corporal punishment<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ghandhi|first=Sandy|date=1984|title=Spare the Rod: Corporal Punishment in Schools and the European Convention on Human Rights|journal=The International and Comparative Law Quarterly|volume=33|issue=2|pages=488–494|jstor=759074}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/25/newsid_2516000/2516621.stm |title=On this day: 25 February. 1982: Parents can stop school beatings |work=BBC News |accessdate=30 January 2017}}</ref>. In other private schools, it was banned in 1998 (England and Wales), 2000 (Scotland) and 2003 ([[Northern Ireland]]).<ref name=CountryUK>{{cite web |url=http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/uk.html |title=Country report for UK |date=June 2015 |publisher=Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children}}</ref> Schools had to keep a record of punishments inflicted,<ref> Department of Education, Administrative Memorandum 531, 1956</ref> and there are occasional press reports of examples of these "punishment books" having survived.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2122724/Records-reveal-corporal-punishment-dished-schools-1970s-Found-cellar-Greenfield-Primary-School-Oldham-Greater-Manchester.html |title=Six blows on the rump! Extraordinary records reveal how corporal punishment was meted out in our schools |work=Daily Mail |location= London |author=Vinter, Phil |date=30 March 2012 |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.corpun.com/uksc9610.htm#490 |title= The good old days, eh? |work=The Independent |location= London |author=Merry, Sam |date=3 October 1996}}</ref>
The implement used in many state and private schools in England and Wales was often a rattan [[caning|cane]], struck either across the student's hands or (especially in the case of teenage boys) the clothed [[buttocks]]. "[[Slippering]]"—striking the buttocks with a rubber-soled gym shoe, or [[plimsoll shoe]]—was widely used in many schools, for example King's School, Macclesfield, a boys grammar school in Cheshire.<ref name=corpunkettering>{{cite web |author=Kettering, David |url= http://www.corpun.com/kettering.htm |title=Behave or bend over for the slipper: UK Grammar School life in the 1960s |website= www.corpun.com |access-date=12 May 2016}}</ref> In a few English cities, a strap was used instead of the cane.<ref name="stopp">''Guide to LEAs' Corporal Punishment Regulations in England and Wales'', Society of Teachers Opposed to Physical Punishment, Croydon, 1979.</ref> In Scotland a leather strap, the [[tawse]], administered to the palms of the hands, was universal in state schools,<ref>"Rise and fall of the belt", ''Sunday Standard'', Glasgow, 28 February 1982.</ref> but some private schools used the cane.<ref>Ahmed, Kamal (27 April 2003). [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/apr/27/labour2001to2005.tonyblair3 "He could talk his way out of things"]. ''The Observer'' (London).</ref>
Prior to the ban in private schools in England, the "slippering" of a student at an independent [[boarding school]] was challenged in 1993 before the [[European Court of Human Rights]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/private-schools-can-beat-pupils-european-court-of-human-rights-expresses-misgivings-on-corporal-1499897.html |title=Private schools 'can beat pupils': European Court of Human Rights expresses misgivings on corporal punishment |first=Adam |last=Sage |work=The Independent |date=26 March 1993 |accessdate=30 January 2017}}</ref> The Court ruled 5–4 in that case that the punishment was not severe enough to infringe the student's "freedom from degrading punishment" under article 3 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. The dissenting judges argued that the ritualised nature of the punishment, given after several days and without parental consent, should qualify it as "degrading punishment".<ref name=Tan>{{cite news |author= Ying Hui Tan |title=Law Report: 'Slippering' pupil is not degrading punishment: Costello-Roberts v The United Kingdom. European Court of Human Rights, Strasbourg, 25 March 1993 |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/law-report-slippering-pupil-is-not-degrading-punishment-costello-roberts-v-the-united-kingdom-1499964.html |newspaper=The Independent |date=26 March 1993 |location=London |accessdate=30 January 2017}}</ref>
''[[R (Williamson) v Secretary of State for Education and Employment]]'' (2005) was an unsuccessful challenge to the prohibition of corporal punishment contained in the [[Education Act 1996]], by several [[headmaster]]s of private Christian schools who argued that it was a breach of their religious freedom.
In response to a 2008 poll of 6,162 UK teachers by the ''[[Times Educational Supplement]]'', 22% of secondary school teachers and 16% of primary school teachers supported "the right to use corporal punishment in extreme cases". The [[National Union of Teachers]] said that it "could not support the views expressed by those in favour of hitting children".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/7649308.stm "A 'fifth of teachers back caning'"]. ''BBC News Online''. 3 October 2008.</ref><ref>Bloom, Adi (10 October 2008). [https://www.tes.com/article.aspx?storycode=6003543 "Survey whips up debate on caning"], ''Times Educational Supplement'' (London).</ref>
===United States=== {{Main article|School corporal punishment in the United States}} There is no federal law addressing corporal punishment in public or private schools. In 1977, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] ruling in ''[[Ingraham v. Wright]]'' held that the [[Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighth Amendment]] clause prohibiting "cruel and unusual punishments" did not apply to school students, and that teachers could punish children without parental permission.
As of 2015, 31 states and the [[District of Columbia]] have banned corporal punishment in public schools, though in some of these there is no explicit prohibition. Corporal punishment is also unlawful in private schools in [[Iowa]] and [[New Jersey]]. In 19 U.S. states, corporal punishment is lawful in both public and private schools.<ref name=USReport>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/country-reports/usa.html "Country report for USA"] (November 2015). 'Global Initiative to End All Corporal Punishment of Children.</ref> It is still common in some schools in the South, and more than 167,000 students were paddled in the 2011-2012 school year in American public schools.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2015/12/corporal-punishment/420420/|title=The States Where Teachers Can Still Spank Students|last=Anderson|first=Melinda D.|website=The Atlantic|language=English|access-date=10 May 2016}}</ref> Students can be physically punished from kindergarten to the end of high school, meaning that even legal [[Adult|adults]] who have reached the [[age of majority]] are sometimes spanked by school officials.<ref name="corpun">{{cite web |url= http://www.corpun.com/counuss.htm |title= Corporal punishment in US schools |author= C. Farrell |date=October 2016 |website= www.corpun.com}}</ref> American legal scholars have argued that school paddling is unconstitutional and can cause lasting physical, emotional, and cognitive harm.<ref> See, e.g., Deana A. Pollard, Banning Corporal Punishment: A Constitutional Analysis, 52 Am. U. L. Rev. 447 (2002); Deana A. Pollard, Banning Child Corporal Punishment, 77 Tul. L. Rev. 575 (2003).</ref>
===Venezuela=== Corporal punishment in all settings, including schools, was prohibited in [[Venezuela]] in 2007. According to the Law for the Protection of Children and Adolescents, "All children and young people have a right to be treated well. This right includes a non-violent education and upbringing... Consequently, all forms of physical and humiliating punishment are prohibited".<ref>[http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/progress/prohibiting-states/venezuela.html "Prohibition of all corporal punishment in Venezuela (2007)"] Global Initiative to End All Corporal school Punishment of Children.</ref>
===Uganda=== In Uganda, teachers usually keep their huge classes calm by corporal punishment. However, there is some movement, who wants them to change disciplining methods by using positive discipline. Teachers should better teach them how to improve, when they performed badly<ref>[https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/uganda-non-governmental-organisation-wants-convince-school-teachers-stopping-corporal "End pupils'fear of teachers' canes (2018)"] in D+C Vol. 45 05-06/2018.</ref>
